The ascendaney of the one order would naturally tend to tlie advancement of the other. For in the growing worldly pomp and splendour of the Churoh, it was natural to expect that communities of men living in evangelical poverty, and professing a life of austerity and self-denial, should meet with encou- ragement and a great share of popularity. As the higher clergy occupied the more exalted stations in society, and were identified with the court, it would naturally follow, that the monastic bodies, taken from the lower orders of the people, should be identified with a popular party, and lead the way in those struggles for independence which were afterwards taken up by the Commoris·

Thus, then, were the M onastic Orders appointed to be the instructors of the great messes of society, and to lead them on the road of improvement and independenoe. Thus were they destined in earlier times to occupy that position as an eeclesiastical body, which was afterwards held by the third estate (as it is called), the oradle of social life and liberty. With some reason, therefore, does a mo- dern writer of great intelligence behold in the advance- ment of these orders a type and example of the struggles of the Commoris. At all events, at the period of which Ι am now speaking, it is not to be questioned but that the Monks represented the popular ecclesiastical party in · England, and what the great mass of the people were to the Norman Barons, the same were the Monks to the more dignified ecclesiastics.
